reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central evaluative scaffold in the essay: repeated appeal to “the correct moral view” and to a unified notion of “mostly-great”/“Flourishing,” including in the trade/threats sections. If that scaffold were illegitimate, it would weaken a substantial chunk of the essay’s comparative assessments (including how threats ‘eat most value’ and how to interpret numeric Flourishing estimates). However, the essay itself partially anticipates the issue by explicitly discussing moral uncertainty and by sometimes shifting to ‘preferred view’ / ‘many views gain from trade’ framing, so the position doesn’t fully depend on a single privileged metric in all places. The objection is directionally right (antirealism undermines mind-independent ‘correctness’), but it overstates the extent to which the whole analysis becomes impossible: an antirealist can still use stance-relative ‘correctness,’ or explicitly adopt a moral-uncertainty aggregation procedure, without conditionalizing everything on realism. Hence moderate strength, good correctness, high clarity, minimal dead weight, and it stays focused on one main issue.
title: Antirealism undermines the single metric needed to evaluate flourishing claims
